text:
I don’t really follow video game websites because there’s only a handful of games I get to play. Most recently, it’s the new FromSoftware game Sekiro. I’ve played and beaten most of their “Soulsborne” franchise.

However, I’ve been seeing a lot of discussion randomly popping up from a side that wants an “easy” difficulty on twitter, and it’s... frustrating to say the least. 

To clarify, there are two distinct camps in that. One wanting one an easier difficulty for accessibility reasons which I’m sympathetic towards, and one that just finds the game too hard (which is where my frustration comes from). I’m not sure if it’s the first time these discussions have come up for the developers, but man is it annoying.
I mean, I just don't have the time or the temperament to deal with Dark Souls games in general
Not those specific games, but that genre of game
Whereas they’re the games I sink my teeth into. I love being challenged as it’s a lot of micro-goals. Each boss is a challenge to conquer, learn, and get better from.
That’s not for everyone and that’s a good thing, in my opinion.
No dog in the fight, but it's not a zero sum game, right? Someone getting an easy mode shouldn't distract from you playing on hard.
It's a bit of a "you should build your deck based on your own skill, guile, and knowlege of cards, not cheating copying someone else's list or using sites like EDHREC" type argument.

I mean, I'm absolutely a better person than those that netdeck, and will get into heaven where they won't, but I can just bask in the satisfaction of knowing that, and not be upset if they copy a list.

A lot of people have that mindset on the pro-difficulty side, which is annoying I’ll admit. 

I think my annoyance is less directed at the notion of an easy mode and more at a vocal minority who are demanding an easier mode.

The best analogy I’ve seen recently is comparing it to that of the horror movie genre (and movies as an art form  on general.)

I detest horror movies personally. I can’t watch them because I’m squeamish to that medium. Like I don’t think I could make it through The Texas Chainsaw or the original Exorcism. That’s fine though. I don’t have to watch them. My cousin is a fiend when it comes to horror movies though. They’re different genres for different people.

I'd liken the difficulty setting demands more to the crowd like the Prof than to netdecking. Prof and folks demand reprints because they want magic on easy mode but don't want to put in the work required to get good despite their restrictions. And while they have a point about accessibility, they go too far too often. Video games of a specific caliber exist and if people aren't willing to do what it takes to get good at them, difficulty settings aren't the actual problem here
I do agree there's a weird entitlement going on in wanting an easy mode. This thing wasn't made for you. I just can't get too worked up about it, but I'm also not a Dark Souls guy.

I'm not either, really, but I get the appeal. I play platformers, smash bros, and RPGs. Even then, though, I recognize the absurdity of avatar strength over player skill. Characters leveling up has always felt stupid to me. That's not how skill works and it's really really arbitrary. Good games make the players improve, not the characters

As a long-time developer of video games, I find it dumb to not include difficulty settings. Balance the top end of your game at whatever target you want, but leaving money on the table that requires only minimal work to pick up is poor business.
My thought process aligns with what Dana said
Dark Souls wasn't meant for me
It was meant for people with Mason's mentality
Is there are story?
The only thing I get really irked about it people who go "Well you're not a gamer because you don't like these games"
Like... Bitch, I play games almost every day, just because they're not the games YOU LIKE doesn't mean shit

I am of the opinion that not everything is for everyone, but I also think that it is a net negative from a business perspective to not try and reach as wide of an audience as you can.

This is similar to how people felt with Fire Emblem Awakening when they added a casual mode that didn’t punish you with permadeath when your units fell in battle. There was a part of the community that was in an uproar about it, but I just played on the normal mode, and it didn’t effect me.

That little change though made the series accessible to a lot more people (like my girlfriend) who was always put off by permadeath. After enough time playing, she eventually worked her way up to playing in the normal mode because she was more accustomed to it, and that was a lot of the response in the community a while later. The fan base grew and it was a better on ramp.

I think that’s all people are really asking for. I know I REALLY was to play Sekiro, but I am a bit put off by what I’ve heard about it’s difficulty. They style of game seems like it’s like it’s for me, but the starting difficulty isn’t.
Yes, Mike, there is a story to the games, but the overall concentration of them has always been how amazingly difficult they can be
Because if there's a story, then it can be sold to a wider audience than the top 10% of elite-talented gamer. And failing to do so, is poor business.
the immense difficulty is almost a marketing streategy by itself
Sure, for niche audience.
I think you'd lose that with an "easy mode"
This goes back to the debate "is it better to cater to all or cater the best to one group"
Sorta. I'm approaching it from a RoI perspective.
But I've got bias.
Having worked for people who are happy to be mediocre because it makes them successful enough, but not caring for the success of the employees,..chaffes.
I think Dark Souls wouldn't be as popular if it wasn't known for its difficulty
I don't think I would've ever heard about it
Same thing with Seriko
Fair enough.

To answer the story question, there is, but it’s usually very cryptic. For Dark Souls, the lore and background is told through item descriptions. There’s not much in the general sense of storytelling. There’s NPCs that you can chat with but mostly the game doesn’t give it to you narratively: you have to seek it out. 

Bloodborne is similar, but it’s easier to piece together from the world. Sekiro has the most upfront story of the genre.

That's all great. If there is a good story worth experiencing, then there's no reason not to include a story mode that makes a game more accessible. The game doesn't have to default to that, and the UX can even use dark patterns to make it inaccessible after some amount of failure.

I know Dean was being sarcastic but what the hell, I’ll take it to hot and heavy anyway :joy:

Magic players are shorty game designers
Shitty*
Lol, yeah, I definitely wasn't serious.
I thought MaRo's tidbit was very interesting
Bolas originally had hybrid r/u in his mana cost

Eh. I felt like airing an unpopular opinion anyway. A ton of speculation comes up around each set and people start hoping for things that, if they had two days of game design experience, they would realize are stupid and bad
Speculation implies a reasonable guess, which I think people forget.
Some people speculate, some people make stupid wishes.

Well we EDH players are particularly egregious about this. We want more Jeskai commanders so we’ll look at art for literally anything and say it’s a Jeskai legend. Nevermind if it’s a picture of a freaking bluebird, we just clamor for things without remembering that the greater Magic populace would in fact prefer a nonlegendary monocolored card because they play *original* Magic. Where fewer colors is a *good* thing. We’re shitty game designers because we only think about ourselves and what *we* want.
It's part of the reason I dont like Khans block; three color cards only work in 1 select three color deck, 4 four color decks, and five color decks. So many of Khans cards weren't playable.
Plus it's an ugly, emotionally cold world
Dana's speculations about WAR were pretty great, though. He called most details about the planeswalkers in the set, really only wrong on the transform mechanic.
I loved khans. I like 3 color worlds. And id like them to hold heir value by showing up where appropriate. Foisting 3 color cards into a guild set is a very bad idea, and obviously so
I agree. Can we go back to Alara now?
I think I made this comment before, but it's wierd. I didn't play Alara and i know the identity of all the shards. I played khans and can't tell the five apart.

That’s a rainbow world now and I don’t think we need new artifact legends in esper. If they go back to shards, it’ll be somewhere new. They get to go to like 4 places a year, and they should be new ones. People act all impatient about revisiting places but either give us a story reason to retread old ground or get out
They could tell the story of Alara through shard colored glasses if they chose
I'm very interested to see how things have changed since the plane was mended

I’m just grumpy about magic players making demands, really. I saw a comment two weeks ago about “THANK GOD there’s no proliferate for the Simic mechanic, can you believe how awful that would have been with planeswalkers in WAR?” Bajillion upvotes. 

Then War spoilers started and proliferate is the marquee mechanic and the walkers are designed to not be OP bullshit in limited, which was always going to be the case. And everyone’s like OMG PROLIFERATE WE KNEW IT and I’m just annoyed at the doublethink of it all.
We’re not even a fourth as clever as we think we are, and while speculation is fun, it dips so easily into absence of reason that it really starts to get wearisome.
I check slack for the 2nd time all weekend and I wasn’t disappointed.
Do you think that proliferate makes sense now that we know many walkers don't have positive loyalty abilities?
It certainly felt like it would have been messy before we saw spoilers, thinking we'd just have typical walkers.
I would have up voted that original comment.
But now I'm definitely all about proliferate

But it was silly to think that we would in the first place. Uncommon walkers were obvious. The immortal sun suppresses walker abilities in the story. If you’ve played a game of Limited in the last two years you’ll know how devastating it can be to face a walker at all. Obviously things were going to change when they made uncommon cards. They don’t even make many non-Aura enchantments in the game because they’re too complex, and walkers are far more egregious. And hat just brings me around to the main point—if we players spent two days designing games, we wouldn’t make such ridiculous demands or obnoxious predictions
Basically whenever you’re designing something that other people will see, use, read, enjoy, or spend any time with, imagine this image hovering over you the whole time:
I feel really called out about the "Jeskai legends" thing, but it's totally true
That's a firin'
Give me an excuse for anything Jeskai and I'll take it. I have newspapers and red string all over my bedroom
I really would like more Legendary Creatures in the shallow-er color combinations
Jeskai being one of them
Didn't think we'd see one in WAR though
I'm actually still surprised how many mono-colored Legendary Creatures we have now. We're at 6
I didn't think we would. But dammit, I'll take anything.
I'd stick to wishing for supplemental products
Also, somewhat current "event": <https://twitter.com/JoshLeeKwai/status/1115012792996655104>

Regarding infect - folks focus on the wrong part of increasing it. It isn’t because it wins, but because one person gets knocked out early and has to sit after the rest of the table clobbers the infect player.

Here's a hot take...I haven't played Magic in over 6 weeks and was really starting to go down a thought path to get out entirely as all of the discussions are so negative and draining. Then, through happenstance, my son and I were able to jam 2 games at the LGS tonight and the second was very fun and interactive, where each deck got to do things and I remember why I love the game.
It's too fun
I very much can be.
The players suck, though. Because, you know, people
They are the worst.
The :notes:wooooorst:notes:
